{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3602324,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T14:27:04.273Z","cooked":"

I dabble in 3d printing at the hobby level, have owned a few Prusas over the years and currently own a Bambu A1. I work at a relatively large metal fab/sheet metal shop full time, and after hearing I have a printer at home, they’ve asked me to provide a couple of recommendations for a 3d printer for use at work.

Unfortunately my knowledge is pretty limited outside the scope of common FRC printer brands such as Bambu, Prusa and Creality. So while not directly FRC related, I figured there may be a few knowledgeable folks in this community that could provide some direction/advice on the topic?

As far as details/requirements of this printer, my work doesn’t really seem to know what they want (or what they want to make with it). I’m guessing this machine will end up being used for custom/1-off tooling and jigs. It’s sounding like they’ve got a rough budget of $35k USD, but are willing to go higher “if needed”. I personally am limiting the scope to FDM based printers with minimal to no post processing needed. This will be the companies first foray into 3d printing, and extra post processing steps with resin or SLS printers I think will just be an added headache.

I’ve heard good things from a few of my FRC teams’ sponsors about Markforged machines, so am planning to reach out to them for some initial quotes. I’m not sure if a company like Stratasys would have anything in their lineup within this budget. I get the feeling I’m stuck a bit in the middle between the higher end hobby grade machines, and the lower end industrial machines.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T14:48:26.540Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":190,"reads":361,"readers_count":360,"score":1052.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":500372,"topic_slug":"3d-printer-for-work","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/3d-printer-for-work/500372/1","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3602345,"name":"Ian Bae","username":"soriiku17","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/soriiku17/{size}/211323_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T14:53:06.692Z","cooked":"

If it’s your company’s first time going into 3d printing, I would get a consumer printer at first to see if its something that they want to continue with. My go to suggestion for an introductory printer would be the Bambu Labs P1S (~$600) or the Anycubic Kobra S1(~$500). Both can print with a wide range of materials and have advanced features. Both are under $1000. If yall want to continue with 3D printing another suggestion would be the Mosaic Element which is a pro grade printer which can print even the most advanced materials. It starts at around $10000 USD. My best suggestion is to get a high end consumer printer such as the Bambu Labs X1C, X1E or the Prusa Core One. $35k doesn’t get too much in the industrial printing world and having this starting base might give yall an idea of what the process is like.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T14:55:32.935Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":305,"readers_count":304,"score":86.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500372,"topic_slug":"3d-printer-for-work","display_username":"Ian Bae","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63388,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"weeeeeeeee"},"post_url":"/t/3d-printer-for-work/500372/2","custom_user_title":"weeeeeeeee","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602347,"name":"Will C","username":"Suppdog222","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/suppdog222/{size}/256515_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T14:53:14.501Z","cooked":"

Haven’t looked into any MarkForged printers recently but I’ve heard good things. If your looking for a printer for work your definitely going to want something that’s fully enclosed, has a hardened steel nozzle and textured PEI build plate, and can reach temperatures of 300-350C. These specs are key if you want to run high-performance materials like nylon, polycarbonate, or carbon fiber blends. BambuLabs is what I usually recommend to people, especially if people new to 3D printing will be using the printer. The X1 Carbon and H2D are both great options to look at as their very capable and reliable machines. Ultimaker is what we use at my work currently and they’ve worked great so far. Id also recommend taking a look at a couple of Prusas new printers like the Core One or HT90

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T14:57:52.845Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":282,"readers_count":281,"score":116.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500372,"topic_slug":"3d-printer-for-work","display_username":"Will C","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66211,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3176 Risk Mitigation Specialist + 3D Printing Lead + Fabrication and Design"},"post_url":"/t/3d-printer-for-work/500372/3","custom_user_title":"3176 Risk Mitigation Specialist + 3D Printing Lead + Fabrication and Design","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602365,"name":"","username":"Alex_Y","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T15:07:00.081Z","cooked":"
Suppdog222:

Haven’t looked into any MarkForged printers recently but I’ve heard good things

In today’s environment, I would only suggest markforged printers if you want to print fiber-reinforced parts. For the price of a markforged printer, you can get multiile H2Ds or X1Es, which are more capable and much faster printers.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T15:07:00.081Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":214,"readers_count":213,"score":122.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500372,"topic_slug":"3d-printer-for-work","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50219,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/3d-printer-for-work/500372/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602493,"name":"Cory","username":"Cory","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cory/{size}/312_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T15:29:36.909Z","cooked":"

$35k is much too much to spend on a single FDM printer in 2025.

Get multiple Bambu X1C’s or H2D’s. They are so cheap and fast it’s silly to buy anything else as a first printer for corporate use. The slicer isn’t as good for inexperienced users as Markforged, but it does allow more customization.

Markforged still has everyone beat in terms of slicer use and almost surefire set it and forget it success, but it is much slower than the Bambu’s. You don’t need more than an onyx one (not sold anymore) or maybe onyx mark two if you want to do fiber reinforced prints.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T15:29:49.022Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":184,"readers_count":183,"score":126.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500372,"topic_slug":"3d-printer-for-work","display_username":"Cory","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":1037,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/3d-printer-for-work/500372/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602496,"name":"Ronnie Sherrer","username":"RonnieS","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ronnies/{size}/198714_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T15:34:23.227Z","cooked":"

Your company sounds like the target market for Markforged. I would get (1) onyx machine to start and make sure it integrates well into your flow then you can buy another.

It will be by far the easiest for people with little knowledge to “Just print the part”. Set it up, stock one material, and have a nice tool that works and a material that is very robust for industry use. A bonus is you guys will be able to play around with weird, custom sheet metal tooling and jigs off the printer. Onyx works extremely well for sheet metal guides, fixtures, prototype dies for a few uses, etc

-Ronnie

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T15:37:04.841Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":165,"readers_count":164,"score":143.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500372,"topic_slug":"3d-printer-for-work","display_username":"Ronnie Sherrer","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19943,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Engineer/part-time coach "},"post_url":"/t/3d-printer-for-work/500372/6","custom_user_title":"Engineer/part-time coach ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"+1","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602505,"name":"","username":"Nick522","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/7ea924/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T15:38:04.335Z","cooked":"

It sounds like this would be a tool used internally and not intended to make products from. To get started I’d recommend you purchase a Bambu Lab H2D so that you can dabble in some low-medium grade engineering filaments and see if 3D Printing is something your company benefits from having. In my experience the machines are very low maintenance and very reliable. In my experience while mark-forged printers don’t require as much attention as a low end Creality product like an ender 3 it is still far from perfection like a Prusa machine or Bambu Lab.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T15:38:04.335Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":152,"readers_count":151,"score":35.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500372,"topic_slug":"3d-printer-for-work","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":75439,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/3d-printer-for-work/500372/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602512,"name":"Ian Osborn","username":"Sands","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/22d042/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T15:42:38.585Z","cooked":"

For a corporate use, I’d go a bit higher than a Bambu. Prusa Core would be my 1st choice.

Bambus are great - but they aren’t full “appliances” (yet).

If you are going to go all in, then there’s a completely different category with Stratasys, Markforged, Creatbot, etc.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T15:42:38.585Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":129,"readers_count":128,"score":45.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500372,"topic_slug":"3d-printer-for-work","display_username":"Ian Osborn","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52040,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/3d-printer-for-work/500372/8","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602517,"name":"","username":"Nick522","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/7ea924/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T15:45:29.174Z","cooked":"

If your company does decide it wants to dive deeper into FDM based printers I would look at the Vision Miner Idex 2. They have ultra high performance printers that use high end engineering grade materials.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T15:45:29.174Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":127,"readers_count":126,"score":25.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500372,"topic_slug":"3d-printer-for-work","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":75439,"username":"Nick522","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/7ea924/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":75439,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/3d-printer-for-work/500372/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3602962,"name":"Lewis","username":"ljruskin","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/l/ebca7d/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T20:00:16.449Z","cooked":"

My only comment, is have logs for hours printed and maintenance, and make sure 1-2 employees are responsible for cleaning the things, and doing said maintenance. I have seen companies thrive on creality, because they had a guy who just sat on them and kept them perfect.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-04-24T20:00:16.449Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":78,"readers_count":77,"score":15.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":500372,"topic_slug":"3d-printer-for-work","display_username":"Lewis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":75354,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2012"},"post_url":"/t/3d-printer-for-work/500372/10","custom_user_title":"2012","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3603013,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-24T20:40:06.299Z","cooked":"

Assuming you’re in a non-national-security setting… Pick up a pair of Bambu X1C before the tariffs hit, a lot of PLA+ for prototypes and some rolls of nylon for production, and see how y’all like it. Total PO in the range of $8k. Get a LOT of filament and a couple maintenance items (spare build plates, spare built hotends, etc).

We use 3x X1C for both prototype and low-volume production of fancy contours that would be a nightmare to cut with conventional subtractive tech, then assemble primarily with heat-set inserts.

If you are nervous about after-sales support, go with Markforged and get a maintenance contract etc through one of their resellers. It’ll be way more expensive than an intern or fab tech cleaning the printers once a week, but that’ll still make sense for certain firms with leaner staffing and carefully defined employee scopes.

Bambulab is Chinese & the primary path for their “print from slicer” option is via an online account that runs through Chinese servers. If network security and information leakage for military applications is a concern, I’d talk to Markforged first.
